    </span><li style="box-sizing:inherit;margin:0.375rem0px"><span>Lines 143-170 pass the hosted card field values, such as the cardholder's name and address, to the</span><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><code class=""><span>POST</span></code><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><span>call in lines 128-131. Anything you pass into the submit is sent to the iframe that communicates with the Orders API. The iframe retrieves the data and sends it along to the</span><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><code class=""><span>POST</span></code><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><span>call. See the</span><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><a href="https://developer.paypal.com/docs/api/orders/v2/" class="undefined dx-external-href" pa-marked="1" title="external link" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" style="box-sizing:inherit;color:rgb(51,122,183);text-decoration:none;background-color:transparent;display:inline-block;white-space:normal;word-break:normal"><span>Orders v2 API</span></a><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><span>for details about billing address fields and other parameters.     </span><li style="box-sizing:inherit;margin:0.375rem0px"><span>Lines 171-173 call the</span><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><code class=""><span>onApproveCallback</span></code><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><span>function from lines 38-97, which sends a</span><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><code class=""><span>POST</span></code><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><span>call to</span><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><code class=""><span>/v2/checkout/orders/{id}/capture</span></code><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><span>that captures the order using the</span><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><code class=""><span>orderId</span></code><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><span>in the</span><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><code class=""><span>data</span></code><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><span>object in</span><span><span>&nbsp;</span></span><code class=""><span>/server/server.js</span></code><span>.</span></li><span>
    </span><li style="box-sizing:inherit;margin:0.375rem0px"><span>Lines 174-178 pass an error message if the payment isn't successful.</span></li><span>

Offer Pay Later, Venmo, and more with Advanced Checkout and extra configuration."},"language":["en-US"],"ecm":{"link":"https://internal.paypalinc.com/contentmanager/space/b7241346-cd3d-4e70-a1c7-74bfd4aaab3d/environment/ddea4eb4-f0c4-4321-aa67-654e40fe9a18/entries/bkZL9fiEJK9aubHgawbWwN","envAllowsPreview":true},"markdownContent":"---\ntitle: Integrate PayPal buttons and Hosted Fields\nslug: /docs/checkout/advanced/sdk/v1/\ncreateTime: '2025-02-24T12:57:55.859Z'\nupdateTime: '2025-05-12T15:53:07.191Z'\n---\n\n\n# Integrate PayPal buttons and Hosted Fields\n\n\n## Version CTA \nThis version of the JavaScript SDK integration guide for direct merchants is a legacy integration. Use [version 2](/studio/checkout/advanced/integrate/) for new integrations.\n\n\n\n## How it works \nExpanded Checkout lets you offer the PayPal payment button and custom credit and debit card fields. This guide covers integrating the PayPal button, credit, and debit card payments. You can find more ways to extend your integration in our [customization doc](/docs/checkout/advanced/customize/) .\n\nOnce you integrate Expanded Checkout, you can also offer options like Pay Later, Venmo, and alternative payment methods with some additional configuration.\n\nThis integration guide follows the code in this [GitHub sample](https://github.com/paypal-examples/docs-examples/tree/main/advanced-integration/v1/) .\n\n\n![advanced-checkout-integration-example.png](https://www.paypalobjects.com/ppdevdocs/img/advanced-checkout-integration-example.png)\n\n**warning**\n**Note:** Discover Checkout's advanced features and unlock greater control over your checkout process by directly integrating with PayPal REST APIs. See [**Get started with PayPal REST API**](/api/rest/) for more information about setting up your own custom integration.\n\n\n\n## Which integration to use \nThere are 2 versions of card payment integrations for direct merchants using the JavaScript SDK:\n\n- **Recommended:** Version 2 uses the PayPal-hosted [CardFields](/sdk/js/reference/#link-cardfields) component to accept and save cards without handling card information. PayPal handles all security and compliance issues associated with processing cards. The CardFields component is the recommended integration method and receives ongoing enhancements and improvements.\n- Version 1 is a legacy integration that uses the [HostedFields](/sdk/js/v1/reference/#link-hostedfields) component. This integration is no longer under active development and wonâ€™t receive further updates.\n\nOther elements of the JavaScript SDK integration for direct merchants remain the same.\n\n\nGitHub Codespaces are cloud-based developer containers that are ready right away. Use GitHub Codespaces to code and test your PayPal integration.\n\n  \n\n\n\n## Integration video \nWatch our video tutorial for this integration:\n\n\n\n## Know before you code \n\n### You need a developer account to get sandbox credentials\n- PayPal uses REST API credentials which you can get from the developer dashboard.\n- Client ID: Authenticates your account with PayPal and identifies an app in your sandbox.\n- Client secret: Authorizes an app in your sandbox. Keep this secret safe and don't share it\n\n\n### You need a combo of PayPal and third-party tools\n\n\n- [JavaScript SDK:](https://developer.paypal.com/sdk/js/)  Adds PayPal-supported payment methods.\n- [Orders REST API:](https://developer.paypal.com/docs/api/orders/v2/)  Create, update, retrieve, authorize, and capture orders.\n- [npm:](https://www.npmjs.com/)  Registry used to install the necessary third-party libraries.\n\n\n\nYou can use Postman to explore and test PayPal APIs.\n\n\n1Check your account setup for advanced card paymentsThis integration requires a sandbox business account with the Advanced Credit and Debit Card Payments capability. Your account should automatically have this capability.\n\nTo confirm that Advanced Credit and Debit Card Payments are enabled for you, check your sandbox business account as follows:\n\n\n\n- Log into the  [PayPal Developer Dashboard](https://developer.paypal.com/dashboard/) , toggle  Sandbox , and go to  Apps \u0026 Credentials .\n- In  REST API apps , select the name of your app.\n- Go to  Features  \u0026gt;  Accept payments .\n- Select the  Advanced Credit and Debit Card Payments  checkbox and select  Save Changes .\n\n\n\nNote:  If you created a sandbox business account through  [sandbox.paypal.com](https://www.sandbox.paypal.com/?_ga=1.158343865.248280996.1670866755) , and the Advanced Credit and Debit Card Payments status for the account is disabled,  [complete the sandbox onboarding steps](https://www.sandbox.paypal.com/bizsignup/#/checkAccount) .\n\n2Check 3D Secure requirementsAdd 3D Secure to reduce the chance of fraud and improve the payment experience by authenticating a card holder through their card issuer.\n\nVisit our  [3D Secure](https://developer.paypal.com/docs/checkout/advanced/customize/3d-secure/)  page to see if 3D Secure is required in your region and learn more about implementing 3D Secure in your app.\n\n3Set up npmOne of the requirements to run this sample application is to have npm installed. For more info,  [visit npmâ€™s documentation](https://www.npmjs.com/package/npm) .\n\n1. Install third-party librariesInstall the following third-party libraries to set up your integration. Here is a sample command to install them all at the same time:\n\n\n#### **`npminstall.sh`**\n```curl\nnpm install dotenv ejs express node-fetch\n```\nSelect any of the links below to see more detailed installation instructions for each library:\n\n| Third-party libraries | Description |\n| --- | --- |\n| [](https://developer.paypal.com/docs/checkout/advanced/sdk/v1/#dotenvthis-zero-dependency-module-separates-your-configuration-and-code-by-loading-environment-variables-from-a-.env-file-into-process.env.)[Dotenv](https://www.npmjs.com/package/dotenv) | This zero-dependency module separates your configuration and code by loading environment variables from a .env file into process.env. |\n| [](https://developer.paypal.com/docs/checkout/advanced/sdk/v1/#ejsthese-templates-help-you-deliver-html-markup-using-plain-javascript.)[ejs](https://www.npmjs.com/package/ejs) | These templates help you deliver HTML markup using plain JavaScript. |\n| [](https://developer.paypal.com/docs/checkout/advanced/sdk/v1/#expressthis-lean-node.js-web-application-framework-supports-web-and-mobile-applications.)[express](https://www.npmjs.com/package/express) | This lean Node.js web application framework supports web and mobile applications. |\n| [](https://developer.paypal.com/docs/checkout/advanced/sdk/v1/#node-fetchthis-function-helps-you-make-api-requests,-similar-to-window.fetch.)[node-fetch](https://www.npmjs.com/package/node-fetch) | This function helps you make API requests, similar to window.fetch. |\n\n\n2. Verify package.jsonA  package.json  file has a list of the packages and version numbers needed for your app. You can share your  package.json  file with other developers so they can use the same settings as you.\n\nThe following snippet is an example of a  package.json  file for a PayPal integration. Compare this sample to the  package.json  in your project:\n\n\n#### **`package.json`**\n```javascript\n\n{\n  \"name\": \"@paypalcorp/advanced-integration\",\n  \"version\": \"1.0.0\",\n  \"description\": \"\",\n  \"main\": \"YOUR-SERVER-NAME.js\",\n  \"type\": \"module\",\n  \"scripts\": {\n    \"test\": \"echo \"Error: no test specified\" \u0026\u0026 exit 1\",\n    \"start\": \"node YOUR-SERVER-NAME.js\"\n  },\n  \"author\": \"\",\n  \"license\": \"Apache-2.0\",\n  \"dependencies\": {\n    \"dotenv\": \"^16.0.0\",\n    \"ejs\": \"^3.1.6\",\n    \"express\": \"^4.17.3\",\n    \"node-fetch\": \"^3.2.1\"\n  }\n}\n```\n\n\n- Pass the name of your server file using  main  by replacing the default  YOUR-SERVER-NAME.js  on lines 5 and 9.\n- Use  scripts.test  and  scripts.start  to customize how your app starts up.\n\n\n\nIf you're having trouble with your app, try reinstalling your local library and package files using  npm install .\n\nIf you're getting the node error below, you need to include  \"type\": \"module\"  in your  package.json  file. This line isn't automatically added when  package.json  is created:\n\nWarning: To load an ES module, set \"type\": \"module\" in the package.json or use the .mjs extension (Use `node --trace-warnings ...` to show where the warning was created)\n\nSee line 6 of the sample  package.json  file for an example.\n\n\n3. Set up .envA  .env  file is a line-delimited text file that sets your local working environment variables. Use this  .env  file to securely pass the client ID and app secret for your app.\n\nThis code shows an example  [.env](https://github.com/paypal-examples/docs-examples/blob/main/advanced-integration/v1/env.example)  file. Rename  .env.example  to  .env  and replace the  PAYPAL_CLIENT_ID  and  PAYPAL_CLIENT_SECRET  with values from your app:\n\nNote:  View your  PAYPAL_CLIENT_ID  and  PAYPAL_CLIENT_SECRET  in your  [PayPal Developer Dashboard](https://developer.paypal.com/dashboard/)  under \"Apps \u0026 Credentials\".\n\n\n#### **`.env`**\n```ruby\nPAYPAL_CLIENT_ID=\"YOUR_CLIENT_ID_GOES_HERE\"\nPAYPAL_CLIENT_SECRET=\"YOUR_SECRET_GOES_HERE\"\n```\n\nThis section explains how to set up your back end to integrate Expanded Checkout payments.\n\nBack-end process\n\n\n\n- Your app creates an order on the back-end by making a call to the  [Create order](https://developer.paypal.com/docs/api/orders/v2/#orders_create)  endpoint of the Orders v2 API.\n- Your app makes a call to the  [Capture payment](https://developer.paypal.com/docs/api/orders/v2/#orders_capture)  endpoint of the Orders v2 API to move the money when the buyer confirms the order.\n\n\n\nBack-end code\n\nThe following example uses 2 files,  /server/server.js  and  /server/views/checkout.ejs , to show how to set up the back end to integrate with Expanded Checkout.\n\n/server/server.js\n\nThe  /server/server.js  file provides methods and functions for making the API calls and handling errors, and creates the endpoints that your app uses to:\n\n\n\n- Generate an access token to use PayPal APIs.\n- Create an order.\n- Capture payment for the order.\n- Simulate errors for negative testing.\n\n\n\nYou'll need to save the  server.js  file in a folder named  /server .\n\n/server/views/checkout.ejs\n\nThe  /server/views/checkout.ejs  file is an Embedded JavaScript (EJS) file that:\n\n\n\n- Generate an access token to use PayPal APIs.\n- Create an order.\n- Capture payment for the order.\n- Simulate errors for negative testing.\n\n\n\nYou'll need to save the  checkout.ejs  file in a folder named  /server/views .\n\n\n#### **`/server/server.js`**\n```javascript\nimport express from \"express\";\nimport fetch from \"node-fetch\";\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\n\nconst { PAYPAL_CLIENT_ID, PAYPAL_CLIENT_SECRET, PORT = 8888 } = process.env;\nconst base = \"https://api-m.sandbox.paypal.com\";\nconst app = express();\napp.set(\"view engine\", \"ejs\");\napp.set(\"views\", \"./server/views\");\napp.use(express.static(\"client\"));\n\n// parse post params sent in body in json format\napp.use(express.json());\n\n/**\n * Generate an OAuth 2.0 access token for authenticating with PayPal REST APIs.\n * See https://developer.paypal.com/api/rest/authentication/\n */\nconst generateAccessToken = async () =\u003e {\n  try {\n    if (!PAYPAL_CLIENT_ID || !PAYPAL_CLIENT_SECRET) {\n      throw new Error(\"MISSING_API_CREDENTIALS\");\n    }\n    const auth = Buffer.from(\n      PAYPAL_CLIENT_ID + \":\" + PAYPAL_CLIENT_SECRET,\n    ).toString(\"base64\");\n    const response = await fetch(`${base}/v1/oauth2/token`, {\n      method: \"POST\",\n      body: \"grant_type=client_credentials\",\n      headers: {\n        Authorization: `Basic ${auth}`,\n      },\n    });\n\n    const data = await response.json();\n    return data.access_token;\n  } catch (error) {\n    console.error(\"Failed to generate Access Token:\", error);\n  }\n};\n\n/**\n * Generate a client token for rendering the hosted card fields.\n * See https://developer.paypal.com/docs/checkout/advanced/sdk/v1/#link-integratebackend\n */\nconst generateClientToken = async () =\u003e {\n  const accessToken = await generateAccessToken();\n  const url = `${base}/v1/identity/generate-token`;\n  const response = await fetch(url, {\n    method: \"POST\",\n    headers: {\n      Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}`,\n      \"Accept-Language\": \"en_US\",\n      \"Content-Type\": \"application/json\",\n    },\n  });\n\n  return handleResponse(response);\n};\n\n/**\n * Create an order to start the transaction.\n * See https://developer.paypal.com/docs/api/orders/v2/#orders_create\n */\nconst createOrder = async (cart) =\u003e {\n  // use the cart information passed from the front-end to calculate the purchase unit details\n  console.log(\n    \"shopping cart information passed from the frontend createOrder() callback:\",\n    cart,\n  );\n\n  const accessToken = await generateAccessToken();\n  const url = `${base}/v2/checkout/orders`;\n  const payload = {\n    intent: \"CAPTURE\",\n    purchase_units: [\n      {\n        amount: {\n          currency_code: \"USD\",\n          value: \"100.00\",\n        },\n      },\n    ],\n  };\n\n  const response = await fetch(url, {\n    headers: {\n      \"Content-Type\": \"application/json\",\n      Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}`,\n      // Uncomment one of these to force an error for negative testing (in sandbox mode only). Documentation:\n      // https://developer.paypal.com/tools/sandbox/negative-testing/request-headers/\n      // \"PayPal-Mock-Response\": '{\"mock_application_codes\": \"MISSING_REQUIRED_PARAMETER\"}'\n      // \"PayPal-Mock-Response\": '{\"mock_application_codes\": \"PERMISSION_DENIED\"}'\n      // \"PayPal-Mock-Response\": '{\"mock_application_codes\": \"INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR\"}'\n    },\n    method: \"POST\",\n    body: JSON.stringify(payload),\n  });\n\n  return handleResponse(response);\n};\n\n/**\n * Capture payment for the created order to complete the transaction.\n * See https://developer.paypal.com/docs/api/orders/v2/#orders_capture\n */\nconst captureOrder = async (orderID) =\u003e {\n  const accessToken = await generateAccessToken();\n  const url = `${base}/v2/checkout/orders/${orderID}/capture`;\n\n  const response = await fetch(url, {\n    method: \"POST\",\n    headers: {\n      \"Content-Type\": \"application/json\",\n      Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}`,\n      // Uncomment one of these to force an error for negative testing (in sandbox mode only). Documentation:\n      // https://developer.paypal.com/tools/sandbox/negative-testing/request-headers/\n      // \"PayPal-Mock-Response\": '{\"mock_application_codes\": \"INSTRUMENT_DECLINED\"}'\n      // \"PayPal-Mock-Response\": '{\"mock_application_codes\": \"TRANSACTION_REFUSED\"}'\n      // \"PayPal-Mock-Response\": '{\"mock_application_codes\": \"INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR\"}'\n    },\n  });\n\n  return handleResponse(response);\n};\n\nasync function handleResponse(response) {\n  try {\n    const jsonResponse = await response.json();\n    return {\n      jsonResponse,\n      httpStatusCode: response.status,\n    };\n  } catch (err) {\n    const errorMessage = await response.text();\n    throw new Error(errorMessage);\n  }\n}\n\n// render checkout page with client id \u0026 unique client token\napp.get(\"/\", async (req, res) =\u003e {\n  try {\n    const { jsonResponse } = await generateClientToken();\n    res.render(\"checkout\", {\n      clientId: PAYPAL_CLIENT_ID,\n      clientToken: jsonResponse.client_token,\n    });\n  } catch (err) {\n    res.status(500).send(err.message);\n  }\n});\n\napp.post(\"/api/orders\", async (req, res) =\u003e {\n  try {\n    // use the cart information passed from the front-end to calculate the order amount detals\n    const { cart } = req.body;\n    const { jsonResponse, httpStatusCode } = await createOrder(cart);\n    res.status(httpStatusCode).json(jsonResponse);\n  } catch (error) {\n    console.error(\"Failed to create order:\", error);\n    res.status(500).json({ error: \"Failed to create order.\" });\n  }\n});\n\napp.post(\"/api/orders/:orderID/capture\", async (req, res) =\u003e {\n  try {\n    const { orderID } = req.params;\n    const { jsonResponse, httpStatusCode } = await captureOrder(orderID);\n    res.status(httpStatusCode).json(jsonResponse);\n  } catch (error) {\n    console.error(\"Failed to create order:\", error);\n    res.status(500).json({ error: \"Failed to capture order.\" });\n  }\n});\n\napp.listen(PORT, () =\u003e {\n  console.log(`Node server listening at http://localhost:${PORT}/`);\n});\n```\n\n\n#### the  /server/server.js  code sample.\n\nDeclare imports\n\n \n\nThis section of code imports the dependencies for your Node.js application:\n\n\n#### **`server.js`**\n```javascript\nimport express from \"express\";\nimport fetch from \"node-fetch\";\nimport \"dotenv/config\";\n```\n- Line 1 imports the Express.js framework to get started with creating a web server.\n- Line 2 imports a  node-fetch  dependency needed to make  http  requests to PayPal REST APIs.\n- Line 3 imports the dotenv library needed for loading sensitive data from environment variables, such as a PayPal client secret.\n\n\nSet up port and server\n\n \n\nThis section of code collects the environment variables, sets up the port to run your server, and sets the base sandbox URL:\n\n\n#### **`server.js`**\n```javascript\nconst { PAYPAL_CLIENT_ID, PAYPAL_CLIENT_SECRET, PORT = 8888 } = process.env;\nconst base = \"https://api-m.sandbox.paypal.com\";\n```\nLines 7-10 start the express Node.js web application framework :\n\n\n\n#### **`server.js`**\n```javascript\nconst app = express();\napp.set(\"view engine\", \"ejs\");\napp.set(\"views\", \"./server/views\");\napp.use(express.static(\"client\"));\n```\nLine 8 declares that the rendering engine uses Embedded JavaScript templates.\n\n\nGenerate client token\n\n \n\nA client token uniquely identifies your payer. You need a client token for the payer so your app can use the hosted card fields. The following code sample creates a client token for you by making a  POST  call to the  /v1/identity/generate-token  endpoint:\n\n\n#### **`server.js`**\n```javascript\n/**\n * Generate a client token for rendering the hosted card fields.\n * See https://developer.paypal.com/docs/checkout/advanced/sdk/v1/#link-integratebackend\n */\nconst generateClientToken = async () =\u003e {\n  const accessToken = await generateAccessToken();\n  const url = `${base}/v1/identity/generate-token`;\n  const response = await fetch(url, {\n    method: \"POST\",\n    headers: {\n      Authorization: `Bearer ${accessToken}`,\n      \"Accept-Language\": \"en_US\",\n      \"Content-Type\": \"application/json\",\n    },\n  });\n\n  return handleResponse(response);\n};\n```\nThis code runs your app on localhost , using the port 8888 that you set up in line 5 of the API call :\n\n\n\n#### **`server.js`**\n```javascript\napp.listen(PORT, () =\u003e {\n  console.log(`Node server listening at http://localhost:${PORT}/`);\n});\n```\n\nRender checkout page\n\n \n\nSet up your app's checkout page to load this section of code when it's rendered by your server:\n\n\n#### **`server.js`**\n```javascript\n// render checkout page with client id \u0026 unique client token\napp.get(\"/\", async (req, res) =\u003e {\n  try {\n    const { jsonResponse } = await generateClientToken();\n    res.render(\"checkout\", {\n      clientId: PAYPAL_CLIENT_ID,\n      clientToken: jsonResponse.client_token,\n    });\n  } catch (err) {\n    res.status(500).send(err.message);\n  }\n});\n\napp.post(\"/api/orders\", async (req, res) =\u003e {\n  try {\n    // use the cart information passed from the front-end to calculate the order amount details\n    const { cart } = req.body;\n    const { jsonResponse, httpStatusCode } = await createOrder(cart);\n    res.status(httpStatusCode).json(jsonResponse);\n  } catch (error) {\n    console.error(\"Failed to create order:\", error);\n    res.status(500).json({ error: \"Failed to create order.\" });\n  }\n});\n\napp.post(\"/api/orders/:orderID/capture\", async (req, res) =\u003e {\n  try {\n    const { orderID } = req.params;\n    const { jsonResponse, httpStatusCode } = await captureOrder(orderID);\n    res.status(httpStatusCode).json(jsonResponse);\n  } catch (error) {\n generateClientToken()  function.\n- Lines 144-147 render the checkout page, pass the  clientId  and  clientToken  to the page, and inject the value into the script tag.\n\n\nRun createOrder()\n\n \n\nThis section of code defines a  createOrder()  callback function for the  [Create orders](https://developer.paypal.com/docs/api/orders/v2/#orders_create)  endpoint of the Orders v2 API. Call the function when the payment is submitted, for example, when the payer selects the PayPal button, or submits a card payment.
